exampleContent.title: Highlight Exercise Examples
exampleContent.description: Learn how to identify and highlight specific types of words or phrases in text
learningPoints: Read the instructions carefully to know what to look for
Scan the text systematically from left to right
Understand the characteristics of the word type you're finding
Context can help you identify the correct words

sections.title: Finding Nouns
sections.description: Learn to identify and highlight nouns (people, places, things, ideas) in sentences

examples.text: The cat sat on the mat in the garden.
examples.explanation: Nouns are words that name people, places, things, or ideas. In this sentence: 'cat' (animal), 'mat' (thing), and 'garden' (place) are all nouns.
examples.tips: Look for words that answer 'who?' or 'what?' in the sentence.

examples.text: The teacher gave the students their homework yesterday.
examples.explanation: Teacher (person), students (people), and homework (thing/concept) are all nouns.
examples.tips: People and objects are usually easy to spot as nouns.

sections.title: Finding Verbs
sections.description: Learn to identify action words and being verbs in sentences

examples.text: The dog runs quickly and jumps over the fence.
examples.explanation: Verbs show action or state of being. 'Runs' and 'jumps' are both action verbs showing what the dog does.
examples.tips: Ask 'what is happening?' or 'what does the subject do?' to find verbs.

examples.text: She is happy and feels excited about the trip.
examples.explanation: 'Is' is a being verb (shows state), and 'feels' is a verb expressing emotion/sensation.
examples.tips: Don't forget about being verbs like 'is', 'are', 'was', 'were'.

sections.title: Finding Adjectives
sections.description: Learn to identify descriptive words that modify nouns

examples.text: The small, red car drove down the busy street.
examples.explanation: Adjectives describe nouns. 'Small' and 'red' describe the car, while 'busy' describes the street.
examples.tips: Adjectives often come before the noun they describe and answer 'what kind?', 'which one?', or 'how many?'

exercises.instruction: Highlight all the nouns in the sentence.
exercises.text: The teacher read a story to the children in the classroom.
exercises.explanation: Nouns are words that name people, places, things, or ideas. Teacher (person), story (thing), children (people), and classroom (place) are all nouns.

exercises.instruction: Highlight all the verbs in the sentence.
exercises.text: The cat runs fast and jumps high.
exercises.explanation: Verbs are action words or words that show what someone or something does. 'Runs' and 'jumps' are both action verbs.

exercises.instruction: Highlight all the adjectives in the sentence.
exercises.text: The big, fluffy dog played in the green grass.
exercises.explanation: Adjectives describe nouns. 'Big' and 'fluffy' describe the dog, while 'green' describes the grass.

exercises.instruction: Highlight all the adverbs in the sentence.
exercises.text: She quickly ran upstairs and quietly closed the door.
exercises.explanation: Adverbs describe verbs and often end in '-ly'. 'Quickly' describes how she ran, and 'quietly' describes how she closed the door.

exercises.instruction: Highlight all the proper nouns in the sentence.
exercises.text: Mary and John visited Paris during their vacation in July.
exercises.explanation: Proper nouns are specific names of people, places, or things and are capitalized. Mary and John (people), Paris (place), and July (month) are all proper nouns.
